abstract.p: Holland Cotter reviews Laylah Ali's gouache-on-paper work at 303 Gallery (S)

block.p: Young American artists continue to deal with political subject matter in interestingly subtle and impersonal ways. Such is the case in the small gouache-on-paper narratives of Laylah Ali, 32, in her first New York solo show.

Her characters are E.T.-like beings, with dark-skinned, stick-figure bodies and round green heads, set against a plain blue ground. The format is like a cartoon strip, though the scenes aren't comedic. Most of the interactions are coercive. Uniformed police, warriors in helmets, and priestlike figures in tall cone-head caps dominate other figures who appear to be prisoners or slaves, some of whom are physically maimed.

Young American artists continue to deal with political subject matter in interestingly subtle and impersonal ways. Such is the case in the small gouache-on-paper narratives of Laylah Ali, 32, in her first New York solo show.

Her characters are E.T.-like beings, with dark-skinned, stick-figure bodies and round green heads, set against a plain blue ground. The format is like a cartoon strip, though the scenes aren't comedic. Most of the interactions are coercive. Uniformed police, warriors in helmets, and priestlike figures in tall cone-head caps dominate other figures who appear to be prisoners or slaves, some of whom are physically maimed.
Ms. Ali skillfully interweaves cultural reference: some costumes look archaic and ''tribal,'' others contemporary. The priests's hats and robes suggest Ku Klux Klan gear.

The work's graphic clarity and spartan palette bring the serial history paintings of Jacob Lawrence to mind. Where the struggles he dramatized are specific, Ms. Ali's are generic, of a kind always happening somewhere some time. Her light, precise, pictographic touch sharpens them nicely: they are like the killer scenarios of video games reprogrammed with a conscience.
